For the American total eclipse a couple-three years ago, D chose to drive the shortest distance possible. (a little lazy and a LOT sick with a bad gut and liver) Since I'm in Central Wisconsin and the path of totality was at right angle to my path right over Jefferson City, MO...that was my goal. I figured I could veer right or left as I got close and adjust for weather, which ended up perfect!
I looked for viewing spots and found that the small airport right in town looked identical to my home airport, so figured the same sort of crowd hung out there...bang on! I rolled in about an hour before sunrise under a clear sky and saw the Mercury Vapor ight of man fighting with the cobalt blue early light of God battling to light the Capital dome. That is one of my favorite photos!...un-filtered and un-manipulated!
The eclipse started rolling around noon, to an audience of about a hundred folks in lawn chairs on the apron. Lots of pix taken of the yellow-orange-red-lit thunderstorms on the horizon...and the funky shadows cast by the trees. (a million crescent-shaped light patches.
Finally the full monty! Like a bullet hole in a sky made of crystal!
Since then, I got a fresh liver, the gut calmed down, and I'm planning another airport run in 2024. Dayton, and the Air Force Museum is right on the path...as is Wapakoneta!

I was listening to an otherwise intelligent podcaster who was acting as if a Solar Eclipse was No Big Deal. It's no big deal until you've experienced it and then you know how weird, wild, and wonderful it truly is. We got one in South Carolina in 2018. I completely understood the concept of the pinhole view box, but when I went to check on Mom on a bench in the shade, every sunbeam shining between the thousands of leaves on the tree cast its own pinhole Eclipse image on the ground.
Then I started wondering, Where else in our Solar system could you witness a similar celestial event?
If you were on the moon, the Earth would Completely block the sun for hours, but you would not see the corona of the sun.

Do you even know what a VPN is, let alone how it works? VPNs can't completely hide your identity or location, regardless of what they claim. That is not what they were originally designed for. They are intended to keep your data secure between your home or mobile computer and a very specific, single LAN. Once you try to extend beyond that, you are leaving any security behind. Back when it was first noticed that you could use a VPN to mask your real location there was some initial success in fooling geofencing, but in the last couple of years every single VPN I have tried has failed to get past geofences because once they realize that's an issue it is actually rather easy to detect the use of a VPN. Once the VPN is detected, if all they want is to enforce the geofence all they have to do is deny access. If they are more interested in getting your identity and real location, there are forensic tools that can do that as well. As for keeping your data safe, that's only good between your device and the VPN servers. Once your connection extends beyond the VPN, there is literally no difference between using a VPN and not using one, meaning a VPN is utterly useless for protecting your data on the Internet at large.

In short, the only way a VPN can actually protect your data is for you to set up your own VPN server, and even then it only protects your data between your own machines, not anything else on the Internet.

There is a whole lot of false advertising going on regarding VPNs these days.

Due to the solar eclipse timelapse photo (7:46) I realised that in the South hemisphere the Sun traces a curve that goes from your right side to your left, which is the opposite of what happens in the North hemisphere.

Essentially in the North hemisphere you turn South to face the Sun therefore East is at your left, while in the South hemisphere you turn North to face the Sun, and so East is at your right.

Now that's how to view an eclipse!

I went to the one in the Limpopo valley years ago (it started in Angola, but from my point of view it was a Limpopo valley eclipse), and I was not at all ready for the sheer beauty of it. For instance, when the corona "bursts out", it's like nothing in this world. Can't describe it. It's worth travelling all the way to Argentina to see something like that, alone. And then there's that "360 degree sunset" all around the edge of the world, as soon as it gets dark enough. And the depth of the navy in the blue of the sky during totality, and all the blues of the whole "dome of the heavens" above. The birds started singing their sunset songs, then they went quiet as the little night set in, and then they sang their dawn chorus for the second time that day.

Short version: Thanks not just for sharing the lovely romance of your Argentinian eclipse, but also for bringing back all those memories.

And although your pictures are great, pictures can't describe this phenomenon. It's even better than it looks from the pictures. To other fans of your channel, I would say: Be willing to travel far, to travel rough, to travel to the edges of your budget, in order to go and see an eclipse.

Mind you, there are risks. The Southern African eclipse happened during generally cloudy conditions. Near Musina/Beit Bridge, there was a break in the clouds very close to the time that the eclipse shadow passed over there; in the Kruger Park, the skies stayed grey all day, and all their eclipse was, was a bit of darkness (and the game lay low, waiting for the weather to improve, so it meant that those who thought they'd kill two birds with one stone, there, ended up killing nothing. I suppose it's nice not to kill birds, but ... ja ... )

It's just the shadow of the Moon, but somehow it feels like one of the most significant events of my life. A full eclipse (without too much cloud) is that dramatic.

When we were going to have a total solar eclipse near my home recently I heard all the hype for months and thought it was just that: hype. "It's just an eclipse, what's the big deal?" At the last minute I decided to hop on my dirt bike and ride solo out into the desert. I was the only human for miles, out in the middle of a prehistoric lava flow.

I'm not a religious or emotional guy... I didn't even shed a tear when my first child was born. I'm not into astronomy or anything like that. But experiencing a total eclipse alone in the middle of nature was the most incredible experience of my life. It moved me to tears. It's just a completely otherworldly experience that can't be explained. I'm so glad to see you guys got to have a similar experience and opted not to hang out in the crowds for it. I never understood it before, but after witnessing one I now understand why people chase total eclipses all around the globe. They're purely magical.

I'm a Mechanical Enginnering student at Oregon State University (in Corvallis Oregon where the US eclipse passed through totality).
I watched the eclipse because of your video, even downloaded the Eclipse app because of you. Heck, I even have a video of the "ground snakes" and would never have known about that because of your video.

So I had this idea... Stick with me here...
Because I noticed one piece of advice that everyone said online on viewing an eclipse... Enjoy it in the moment. Meaning just sit there and don't take pictures and try to "capture the moment" instead of living in it.
The dilemma? You still want pictures to remember the event by.
Here's the idea:
What if there was a solar tracking eclipse rig that was totally automated (and open source)?
Like, what if this rig could automatically move your camera to track the eclipse AND, get this, Remove the solar filter in response to the Solar Eclipse app?
This would make everything totally hands free and you could have multiple rigs set up. Then all you'd have to do is sit back, relax, and enjoy the 2+ minute event with your loved ones and remember it (in your mind) for a lifetime.

I had this idea back in the last eclipse, but watching your video (seeing you go back and forth to each camera) this just solidifies the need for this idea to me.

G'day Destin, you were not too far from me for the eclipse.  I too checked out Bella Vista and learned they were expecting 5,000 people (found out later that the numbers were closer to 7,000!!).  I ended up walking 15 minutes up a hill right next to my accommodation in Las Flores (10km drive from Bella Vista).  I also recognised the stop you made at the shop in the middle of nowhere at Talacasto.  For the next eclipse you need to put a white sheet on the ground to check for shadow bands.  The group I was with saw a fantastic display (my first sighting of shadow bands - took 5 eclipses to see them) and we also got a wonderful but brief sighting of Bailey's Beads just a split second before second Diamond Ring.  If you can make it to Australia for the 1 minute long eclipse in 2023 then that would be cool :)

I've always been good at math and this is a really stupid question and I feel ashamed to ask it, but why can't you the square of a distance equal an even larger distance (instead of an area), when it makes perfect sense when you abstract it to numbers? We've always learned in school that something to the first power is distance, second power is area, and third power is volume.

If I took one mile and squared it, it'd be 1 mile in distance (instead of one square mile)

If I took 0.5 miles and squared it, It'd be 0.25 miles in distance (instead of one square mile)

If I took 5,280 ft and squared it, it'd be something waaay larger.



Why do the same distances squared equal any number in distance when it should be fixed? Is this because you can essentially replace this seemingly fixed into an infinite amount of smaller units, turning it into a y=x² equation? When I apply it to real life, it seems to confuse me🤯😵 i feel like I'm making it harder than it needs to be
